Forecast: $2.433 (down from $2.436 last week). US gas prices are seasonal (thanks @Emil for pointing that out) with January prices being cheaper on average than August prices by about 35 cents per gallon because summer gas is more expensive to produce and demand is higher; "Historically, retail gasoline prices tend to gradually rise in the spring and peak in late summer when people drive more frequently. Gasoline prices are generally lower in winter months. Gasoline specifications and formulations also change seasonally. Environmental regulations require that gasoline sold in the summer be less prone to evaporate during warm weather. This requirement means that refiners must replace cheaper but more evaporative gasoline components with less evaporative but more expensive components. In 2000 through 2018, the average monthly price of U.S. retail regular-grade gasoline in August was about 35 cents per gallon higher than the average price in January." https://www.eia.gov/energyexplained/gasoline/price-fluctuations.php USING HISTORICAL GAS PRICES TO CALCULATE A SEASONALLY ADJUSTED FORECAST [latest price] => 2.642

A simple linear regression of Brent crude prices against the national average gasoline price suggests that a gallon will be $2.54 & $2.56 in December and January. Data was downloaded from EIA Short Term Energy Outlook. Futures prices suggest a similar outcome. St Error of estimates suggest 68% of observations should fall between $2.41 and $2.67. Analysis assumes fixed costs related to refining, transportation, sales, taxes, etc remain fixed.  I see 4 factors that could impact gasoline prices:
- demand/refining costs
- slowing global growth
-hurricanes in the Gulf
- geopolitical tensions in the Middle East I think markets are under-pricing geopolitical risks, hurricanes Cat 2 or stronger hit the gulf region on average every other year. A category 4 or higher storm occurs on average once every 15 years. This would likely shut down refineries and increase costs at the pump. On the downside, however so-called “winter blends” for gasoline are cheaper since they are less refined. As a result, Refiner Resale prices fall in December by about $0.20 compared to August. Lastly, global growth is expected to slow which could create additional downside risks for oil and subsequent gas prices. In aggregate, I think these factors support the downside more than the upside.

After the attack on the Saudi oil refineries this last weekend this is a Time update.

*Theoretically* world oil markets are still well supplied knocking out 2.27 mb/d.   However, it removes all spare capacity.    Prices have surged 20%.    Latest repair estimates are that it will take months, not weeks, to restore capacity.  My projections had been for oil prices to decay, based on declining consumption.   That decline may, or may not, be delayed.  I am shifting price expectations up .46 tentatively to 2.81.
  However, this also shows that the Saudi's have been incredibly lax.   They have no perimeter defense around their oil fields or facilities.   And they should have constant air and ground, as well as fixed facilities in place.  They chose to engage in a ground war in Yemen, as a proxy for Iran - and ignored even rudimentary defenses. They value Aramco at $2T. This facility was its largest facility - it deserves security commensurate.  By the way - you can kiss that Aramco $2T Ipo away.  No one is going to invest in an IPO where your assets can get blown away by $50K in remote drones. Will adjust lower, if as I hope, the market can shrug off this action, and if the saudi's get their act together on defense; and if they can get the facilities back on line.

Saudi oil cut in half.
I think outage will be short lived.  But shading due to fud for a day or two

Setting some starting points for future research:
1. EIA publishes historical data going back to the 90s - feels like a time series model may not be a bad place to start
2. Do Bank/Asset Managers forecast gasoline prices. There are certainly forecasts for Crude, which could be used to create a build-up model along with refining and transportation costs
3. Speaking of refineries, hurricane season could adversely affect refinery capacity and drive the price up
4. Refineries and crude impact supply, but what about demand? Long-term trends towards electric cars don't seem likely to be game-changers in the next 4 months. Travel is also lower in the winter (though may spike for the holiday season) and environmental additives aren't required Before I get the chance to really dig in and do my own research, I'll start with the EIA's STEO forecast (https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=39112) the chart is a bit difficult to read, but it shows the Dec, 2019 price at ~$2.50. Based on Standard Errors, I calc'd the St Dev at about $0.25. That would suggest that 68% of results would be within $2.25 to $2.75. Half of that is within the $2.40-$2.65 ranges, but a symmetrical distribution would suggest there is more risk on the downside. That downside risk is further supported by the negative skew in recent (rolling 1-year) gasoline prices. More analysis to come (hopefully).
Shifting my forecast lower as gas prices have continued to fall.

I hadn't seen this GasBuddy chart before. It has U.S. retail gas prices for 1 Month, 3 Months, 6 Months, 9 Months, 1 Year, 18 Months, 2 Year, 3 Year, 4 Year, 5 Year, 6 Year, 8 Year, 9 Year, and 10 Year. Eyeballing the 10 year chart, it breaks it into four month periods, about the time left on this question. So, how much variability is typical? Let's say each line on the Y axis is ~0.20 cents of variability. Roughly 1/3 stays within a $0.20 range over 4 months, 1/4 range over $0.40, and 1/3 can range over $0.60 cents. Beyond that is low probability. Current price is $2.72. The $0.40 range is roughly $2.52-$2.92, with 58% probability. So, think I'm going to tighten the probability a bit into the first 4 options and cut the highest option in half and leave a hedge. https://www.gasbuddy.com/Charts
As pointed out there is uncertainty and volatilty and geopolitics. If this was easy we could make money on it.

The question of seasonality was bothering me. So, I went through each year from 1991-current and took the final week and compared it to the average for the year. It's 28 years. Of those years, 9/28 (32%) were positive and 19/28 (68%) were negative. Average for all years was -0.14. Average for the negative years was -0.28. Average for positive years was 0.14. Average for 2019 at this moment is $2.508. How do mid-year averages compare to full-year? Good question! And, because I'm mental, I went ahead and modified an R Script I had to go through and compare the current year by week to previous years, select the five closest since 2000 and display them in a graph that you can find here: https://cafebedouin.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/gas-prices.png If we take 2005 and 2007 from the graph as reference years, it gives us a range of ~$2.20 to $2.95. If we take the average approach above (not bothering our little heads that mid-year averages aren't the same as full year averages), it suggests a mid-point of $2.35 with a range of $2.07 to $2.64. Doing straight walk through weekly gas numbers for last 10 years, I get:: 0.147: Bin 1 - <2.4
0.149: Bin 2 - 2.4 to <=2.65
0.348: Bin 3 - 2.65+ to <2.95
0.183: Bin 4 - 2.95 to <=3.15
0.173: Bin 5 - 3.15+ All of which is a long way to say that there's a lot of uncertainty here ladies and gents. Best to hedge your bets.
Missed the buckets??? And... man am I at variance from the crowd.

Great work Nigel. Risks:
Hurricane:  (Upside) destruction of platforms such as 2005 which shut down 17% of US oil production for 8 months.
Decreased US Shale:   (upside) Production has dropped 1 million barrels over the last year, due to disciplined cash expenditures
Mergers & Acquisitions (upside) Consolidation imposing even more disciplined cash flow.
Additional Pipelines (downside) Additional haulaway capicity.
Iran Deal (downside)  Iranians bartering oil with the EU for non-sanctioned items; or a more general trade agreement. 
Venezuela (Upside) Citgo control battles 
Global recession (Downside) global demand slowing.  China is already awash in cheap Iranian and Venezuelan oil
Straights of Hormuz Conflict (Upside) Unlikely to affect prices in December.
Seasonal Gas (Downside) Easier to refine.
Early Cold Winter (Upside) 
China/US trade deal (upside)
Baker Hughes rig count (Upside):  Well completion is 2 weeks, with date to first production at 22 days and heading lower.  So the falling rig count eventually yields falling oil output. 
DUCs:  (Upside) Drilled uncompleted well inventory drop .5% between May/June on 8200 DUCS  - so a lot of capacity is there.
Drilling activity:  (Upside) Decreases in the late part of the year due to weather. 
Opec maintains output cuts (Downside) 12/18:  $2.35
12/17   $2.42
12/16   ~$2.35
12/15    $2.00 I am most concerned about pricing discipline and US out put cuts.  My gut
<$2.40  60%
<$2.65  40% Falling production:  40/50/10;  Iranian deal 50/45/5

Adjusting for the latest price. Additionally, I am taking into account seasonality. Based on past data going back to 2011, the average price in December tends to be about 0-20% lower than the average price in June. I have shifted down by 10 percentage points my distribution obtained using Geometric Brownian Motion which assumes no seasonality. I have also adjusted slightly for the Inside View that the Trump administration may choose to keep the price lower through e.g. further use of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve as discussed in my initial post. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/856853

Gasoline price is the result of cost of production, distribution and taxes, adjusted by supply and demand. Main cost of production is naturally the price of oil.
Comparing historical price series, I found a very strong correlation between oil [2], [3] and gasoline prices [1], stronger with Brent than WTI. I will use Brent for the calculations. Base case with a simple random walk model shows gasoline behavior for brent prices below $50 and over $90 per barrel. Range $50 to $90, the most likely one, outputs $2.40 to $2.90 per gallon.
I focus on Brent price for the moment. Brent distribution at 30/12/19 seems to be 10% - 35% - 40% - 15% for ranges [<$50, $70, $90, >$90]
The US Energy Information Administration, in their Annual Energy Outlook 2019 [4] is projecting $75/b for 2019 and 2020.
However, some geopolitics impacts should be considered:
- End of Iranian oil waiver, as step in the US decision to terminate the nuclear agreement [5], with reaction from the EU [6]
The end of the waiver will worsen Iran's economic situation, already seriously damaged to the point of questioning the system [7]
- Venezuela's production cuts are expected to increase shortly [8], but Russia and China will maintain support. China might be pushed by US trade agreements, but it seems it's not happening.
- Short term increase in inventories in the US, suggesting that demand is weakining. Production in US hit a record-high in April [9]. This should be considered as short term, showing a trend but more uncertain as of 30/12/19.
- Saudi Arabia is expected to increase production, from producers [10] and also US [11]. I assume it is in KSA interest to increase production, reduce price and make US oil less profitable.
- Saudi Arabia's economy might be suffering, as per some indicators as Aramco bonds [12] or unemployment rates.
- It is uncertain (to me) what US position would be, as high price would benefit US coporations but damage economy, still strong and early for 2020 presidentials.
- Anecdotical interest on Anadarko, with huge shale assets in America's Permian Basin, by Occidental and Chevron [13]
- Adding to this, chances of a recession in the US before 31/12/19 are low. All in all, many ups and downs in the mid term projections of the Brent price. I would go to an increase in the $70 - $90 range's probability by 15 points, from both >$90 and <$50. Also, reduce the weight of short term impacts, adding uncertainty heading to end of the year. I see gas prices dancing along a line drawn by the various economic and political forces. There is some minimum that below which many of the companies cannot be as profitable and a maximum at which political forces will try to drive the prices down in the coming election year. Then there is Valenzuela and the middle east that could add further volatility.  Of course there are other factors as well including seasonality. My guess is that prices will be higher than last year and the price might rise above the $3.15 point but then settle back to between $2,80 and $3.00.

Outside View: As with other market questions, I use a base rates in the form of a distribution of historical daily (in this case, weekly) movements in the price. I use this distribution to project many Random Walks over the time period, which produces a distribution for where the price will end up by the end of the question's timeline. In this case, I use data from here: [1] Result: 6.0, 16.96, 27.22, 25.15, 24.67 Inside view: Price of gasoline is comprised of:
- crude oil price, which will exhibit the largest volatility
-refining costs
-distribution and marketing
-taxes The above data is based on weekly price data since 1991. The secular change that occurred in the U.S. oil industry, namely, the shale revolution, is effectively acting as a cap on prices because producers are ready to ramp up if prices rise high enough. This effect is not fully represented in the data sample used above.  Seasonal patterns may likewise have an effect beyond the base rates (which are agnostic to what time of year it is). My prior is that there is less driving in the winter and that may push the price lower a bit. Testing the seasonal effect statistically will be the subject of future posts. Finally, I am apprehensive of falling for fundamental attribution bias but perhaps one ought to consider the fact that there is a president in the White House who seems particularly averse to high gas prices and may be willing to intervene, namely through the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which he has done before [2]. The upcoming election year in 2020 will provide a further incentive for him to do so. Therefore, I am reducing the chances of >3.15 [1] https://www.eia.gov/petroleum/gasdiesel/
[2] https://seekingalpha.com/article/4200849-trump-signals-drawdown-strategic-petroleum-reserve I welcome any feedback on anything I might have missed.
